learning_outcomes.description: In-Depth Knowledge - Beams: The student will be able to analyse and design a reinforced concrete beam for flexure/bending and shear. The student will be able to analyse a reinforced concrete beam for serviceability response and calculate and evaluate deflections and crack control in accordance with the relevant code, AS3600. The student will be able to detail the reinforcement of a beam to comply with the regulations set out in AS3600.

In-Depth Knowledge - Columns: The student will be able to analyse and design both slender and stocky reinforced concrete columns. The student will be able to analyse the biaxial bending behaviour of a column in accordance with the relevant code, AS3600. The student will be able to detail the reinforcement of a column to comply with the regulations set out in AS3600.

In-Depth Knowledge - Slabs: The student will be able to analyse and design a reinforced concrete slab. The students will be able to calculate design bending moments and shears using codified analysis techniques and the Hillerborg Strip method. The student will be able to analyse a reinforced concrete slab for serviceability response and calculate and evaluate deflections and crack control in accordance with the relevant code, AS3600. The student will be able to detail the reinforcement of a slab to comply with the regulations set out in AS3600.

Technical Knowledge (Concrete Technology): The student will be able to identify and describe the fundamental properties of concrete. The students will be able to specify the appropriate types of concrete for a range of environments. They will understand and be able to describe how the technology of the concrete and short and long term performance is related.
Hands-on skills - The laboratory classes will provide students with the opportunity to develop practical hands-on knowledge of working with concrete and reinforcing steel.
Critical Thinking: The student will be able to apply analysis and design skills to unfamiliar structural elements and applications.
Communication: The student will demonstrate an ability to effectively communicate the results of engineering analysis and design to other engineers or professionals.

assessments.task_description:
Summative and formative quiz questions included with the Weekly Concrete Technology Modules.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
COMPULSORY 60-minute multiple-choice closed-book examination covering Concrete Technology. This is the only assessment covering Concrete Technology component of the course.

The exam will be held on a Saturday in the mid-semester exam block as per https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/exam-timetables-and-venues/important-exam-dates.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.due_date:
Week 4 - Week 13

Group will complete all report requirements (calculations etc) during the prac classes.

Students should consult their personal timetable to confirm the TWO dates they are required to attend the prac classes.
assessments.task_description:
Students must attend 2 practical classes. Students will undertake calculations as a group during the prac class.

To access the concrete prac classes it is a mandatory requirement that you have

  • Completed the U/G Student Lab Safety Induction Assessment (UGRD01) prior to attending a practical experiment session. Students only have to complete the assessment once during their undergraduate degree. (by Friday of week 3)
  • Steel capped safety boots & Safety glasses
  • Your student ID card

If you do not have all of these items at the time of your first prac, you will NOT be permitted to access the laboratory.

Suitable clothing is as follows:

  • lab coats are NOT required
  • students must wear shirts with sleeves (no singlet tops) and suitable shorts/pants. Very short shorts are not permitted - shorts should come to the knee.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Group will complete all calculations during the prac classes.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture (Reinforced Concrete)

During lectures key concepts in reinforced concrete design are introduced. Examples of the design principles being developed are given. The lectures signpost the way for students to learn in the workshops, practical sessions and their own study. Discussion and questions are encouraged.

A detailed outline of lecture topics is available on the BlackBoard site.

  • Reinforced Concrete Lectures will be in person

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture (Reinforced Concrete) During lectures key concepts in reinforced concrete design are introduced. Examples of the design principles being developed are given. The lectures signpost the way for students to learn in the workshops, practical sessions and their own study. Discussion and questions are encouraged. A detailed outline of lecture topics is available on the BlackBoard site. Reinforced Concrete Lectures will be in person

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Workshop

In the workshop sessions the students can apply the techniques presented in lectures to solve problems. The workshops provide the students with the opportunity to discuss any questions which arise from the lectures and the practical sessions with the tutor, teaching staff and amongst themselves.

The independent completion of workshop is the single most significant learning activity students will undertake for the reinforced concrete design component.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06, L07

The independent completion of workshop is the single most significant learning activity students will undertake for the reinforced concrete design component.

learning_activities.topic:
Prac Classes

Students will attend two practical sessions as per their personal timetable.

In these sessions the students will work in a group of approximately 12 -14 students to design, construct and test 2 reinforced concrete beams. The group will be responsible for analysing the aggregates; designing the concrete mix; designing and constructing the reinforcing cage; mixing and placing the concrete; and testing the beams to failure.

Learning outcomes: L01, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Prac Classes Students will attend two practical sessions as per their personal timetable. In these sessions the students will work in a group of approximately 12 -14 students to design, construct and test 2 reinforced concrete beams. The group will be responsible for analysing the aggregates; designing the concrete mix; designing and constructing the reinforcing cage; mixing and placing the concrete; and testing the beams to failure.
